newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam coffee official predicts bumper harvest.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam coffee official predicts bumper harvest.

text.p: Vietnam's next coffee crop is expected to be a bumper harvest with yields of robusta and arabica reaching as much as 350,000 tonnes, according to the head of the Vietnam Coffee Corporation (Vinacafe).
Tran Khai, was quoted by the English-language Vietnam News on Saturday as saying the 1997/98 crop would amount to Vietnam's biggest so far.
But he added that the state would need to provide some $45 million in low interest loans to protect coffee growers from world price fluctuations.

The government has shown increased concern in recent months over the impact of world price fluctuations on its rural population and Vietnam's leaders have called for efforts to restore a system of farmers' cooperatives.
Output from Vietnam's 1996/97 coffee crop, nearly all of which was exported, reached some 270,000 tonnes. The vast majority was robusta beans used for making instant coffee.
The annual harvest season begins in October. This year has seen favourable weather conditions so far in the main producing areas of the central highlands.
